Diagnosis: Bacterial conjunctivitis Justification: Rapid onset eye redness, tearing, and swelling after activity suggests infectious conjunctivitis, which is common in active individuals and contagious.  2. Diagnosis: Viral conjunctivitis Justification: Similar presentation to bacterial conjunctivitis with tearing and redness, often following exposure to infected individuals, albeit slightly less common post-sport without systemic symptoms.  3. Diagnosis: Corneal abrasion Justification: Recent physical activity (soccer) increases risk of minor trauma to the eye, which can cause redness, tearing, and swelling.  4. Diagnosis: Allergic conjunctivitis Justification: Can cause eye redness, swelling, and tearing, although less likely acutely after sports without allergen exposure noted.  5. Diagnosis: Traumatic hyphema Justification: Eye trauma during sports can lead to bleeding into the anterior chamber, causing swelling and redness, though initial presentation may be subtle.  6. Diagnosis: Uveitis Justification: Less common post-exercise but can cause redness, pain, and tearing; usually associated with other systemic symptoms or known autoimmune disease.  7. Diagnosis: Foreign body in the eye Justification: Playing soccer, potential for debris or foreign object drawing tears and causing local inflammation.  8. Diagnosis: Conjunctival cyst or mass Justification: Less likely given acute onset; considered if symptoms persist or worsen.  9. Diagnosis: Episcleritis Justification: Causes redness and mild swelling, often painless, but less associated with recent activity or tearing.  10. Diagnosis: Acute angle-closure glaucoma Justification: Usually presents with sudden painful eye and vision changes; unlikely without pain or visual disturbance in description.
